items.title: Warning: a recent release failed
items.body: The release PR #60 is still in a pending state after several hours

items.title: Cannot put with a non-encoded column name. Regression in 0.32.x versions.
items.body:
Our samples had a single spot where we weren't encoding https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples/blob/ec2561823c0254cfc126d6e3f83d9bd0c21e19c4/bigtable/hello_happybase/main.py#L53

This used to work. The sample likely should encode there but I think the change made to how we process row changes https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-python-happybase/commit/50c1562afe5cd768ee2804fede9729bc4945f384 is likely related.

I think we may need to guard against the no mutations error seen below in the call stack, but that doesn't explain why the encoding issue is present. 

Also, it would be good to have a test do what the below sample does (not encoding) and assert on the failure. This doesn't seem to have coverage as the tests keep passing

```
print('Writing some greetings to the table.')
        table = connection.table(table_name)
        column_name = '{fam}:greeting'.format(fam=column_family_name)
        greetings = [
            'Hello World!',
            'Hello Cloud Bigtable!',
            'Hello HappyBase!',
        ]

        for i, value in enumerate(greetings):
            # Note: This example uses sequential numeric IDs for simplicity,
            # but this can result in poor performance in a production
            # application.  Since rows are stored in sorted order by key,
            # sequential keys can result in poor distribution of operations
            # across nodes.
            #
            # For more information about how to design a Bigtable schema for
            # the best performance, see the documentation:
            #
            #     https://cloud.google.com/bigtable/docs/schema-design
            row_key = 'greeting{}'.format(i)
            table.put(row_key, {column_name): value})
```
the last line should be ` table.put(row_key, {column_name.encode('utf-8'): value})` but this used to work. 

This is the callstack of the failure:
```
________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ test_main _________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/table.py", line 428, in put
    batch.put(row, data)
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/batch.py", line 167, in put
    column_qualifier).encode('utf-8')]
KeyError: b'cf1:greeting'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/api_core/grpc_helpers.py", line 79, in next
    return six.next(self._wrapped)
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 364, in __next__
    return self._next()
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/grpc/_channel.py", line 358, in _next
    raise self
grpc._channel._Rendezvous: <_Rendezvous of RPC that terminated with:
	status = StatusCode.INVALID_ARGUMENT
	details = "No mutations provided"
	debug_error_string = "{"created":"@1548370439.592426000","description":"Error received from peer","file":"src/core/lib/surface/call.cc","file_line":1036,"grpc_message":"No mutations provided","grpc_status":3}"
>

The above exception was the direct cause of the following exception:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/bigtable/hello_happybase/main_test.py", line 32, in test_main
    table_name)
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/bigtable/hello_happybase/main.py", line 75, in main
    table.put(row_key, {column_name: value})
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/table.py", line 428, in put
    batch.put(row, data)
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/batch.py", line 275, in __exit__
    self.send()
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/batch.py", line 111, in send
    table.mutate_rows(list(self._row_map.values()))
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/bigtable/table.py", line 508, in mutate_rows
    return retryable_mutate_rows(retry=retry)
  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/bigtable/table.py", line 684, in __call__

  File "/Users/crwilcox/workspace/python-docs-samples/.nox/py36-sample-bigtable-hello_happybase/lib/python3.6/site-packages/google/cloud/bigtable/table.py", line 746, in _do_mutate_retryable_rows
    for response in responses:
```

items.title: Table.put is failing in samples due to TypeError: 'dict_values' object does not support indexing
items.body:
Caused once you upgrade to version 0.32.0. The tests also fail at current 0.31.0 but for different reasons.

https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/python-docs-samples/tree/master/bigtable/hello_happybase

items.title: AttributeError: 'Instance' object has no attribute 'copy'
items.body:
I've updated google-cloud-happybase to 0.31.0 and here what happens when I try to initiate connection to BigTable: 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/my_username/Projects/my_project/storage/bigtable/bigtable_storage.py", line 277, in <module>
    BIGTABLE_STORAGE = _create_default_bigtable_storage()
  File "/Users/my_username/Projects/my_project/storage/bigtable/bigtable_storage.py", line 45, in _create_default_bigtable_storage
    return BigtableStorage(instance)
  File "/Users/my_username/Projects/my_project/storage/bigtable/bigtable_storage.py", line 61, in __init__
    self._connection = happybase.Connection(instance=instance)
  File "/Users/my_username/.virtualenvs/my_venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/google/cloud/happybase/connection.py", line 175, in __init__
    self._instance = instance.copy()
AttributeError: 'Instance' object has no attribute 'copy'
```
I make connection in a way that is proposed in [documentation](https://google-cloud-python-happybase.readthedocs.io/en/latest/happybase-package.html#api-behavior-changes):
```
def _create_default_bigtable_storage():
    client = bigtable.Client(project=settings.BIGTABLE_PROJECT_ID, admin=True)
    instance = client.instance(settings.BIGTABLE_INSTANCE_ID)
    instance.reload()
    return BigtableStorage(instance)
```

From requirements.txt:
```
google-cloud-happybase==0.31.0
google-cloud-bigtable==0.31.0
google-cloud-core==0.28.1
```

items.title: 'Connection' ctor uses missing `instance.copy`
items.body:
From: https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-python-happybase/pull/41#issuecomment-425821509

https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-python/commit/86102c959c6852d6b02c2fe3ddeea946a003bee6#diff-7cb26d3f6a9d474a951ae6ff1af2ce71 removed `Instance.copy`, but the `Connection` constructor [still uses it](https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-python-happybase/blob/24de0cbe5edbcde13c213148b9a0652733b92e17/src/google/cloud/happybase/connection.py#L175).

items.title: Migrate to kokoro
items.body: The tests in this repository are still using travis for CI.  We need to get this moved over to kokoro.

items.title: Update pypi release for `pip install google-cloud-happybase`
items.body: The release present in pypi (https://pypi.org/project/google-cloud-happybase/) is severely outdated. Please make a release reflecting the changes in the bigtable api.

items.title: google.cloud.happybase.table.Table.rows is slow
items.body:
My team has an instance of BigTable where we store time series. There are 58,000,000 entries in our BigTable. There are only 22 columns in 3 column families.

This call takes approximately 5 minutes:
```python
keys = [b'some_key_1', b'some_key_2']
columns = [b'some_column_family:some_column]
happybase_table.rows(keys, columns=columns)
```

And this calls take about 1 second in total:
```python
keys = [b'some_key_1', b'some_key_2']
columns = [b'some_column_family:some_column]
for key in keys:
    happybase_table.row(key, columns=columns)
```

items.title: Needs to be updated to use latest bigtable
Memory leak when scanning large table
items.body:
I'm currently using bigtable for archival of tsdb data. When attempting to restore, I find that I have to frequently release the table.scan() cursor, or my memory usage skyrockets (will consume 32gb within an hour). With checkpointing in place and new cursors, I am not seeing this issue. Is this working as intended?

I've created 2 gists to demonstrate the behavior, both of which assume they're running on a GCE instance with local instance credentials granted the necessary BT roles.
https://gist.github.com/clusterfudge/3fe40f7f55e8a2a80c65dbd8e8d6764e - implements checkpointing, has a reasonable and stable memory footprint

https://gist.github.com/clusterfudge/3a2e6b484d24070b6f43fd3fd989e229 - simple single call to scan, will consume all memory available, stopped only by the heat death of the universe.

items.title: Update homepage and API URLs in README
items.body:
The [`README.rst`](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python-happybase/master/README.rst) file currently has the following links:

> *  [Homepage](https://googlecloudplatform.github.io/google-cloud-python/)
> *  [API Documentation](https://googlecloudplatform.github.io/google-cloud-python/stable/)

However, those are pointing to the generic `google-cloud-python` site and API, not the `google-cloud-python-happybase` site and APIs.

For APIs, looks like the correct URL is http://google-cloud-python-happybase.readthedocs.io/ but I'm not sure if there's an equivalent URL for the homepage, or if that should just be omitted.

items.title: KeyError when trying to do `counter_inc`
items.body:
I'm not sure why but `counter_inc` method is not working, no emulator, pointing to a development real instance. 

Snippet:


```python
from google.cloud import bigtable
from google.cloud import happybase

client = bigtable.Client(project='robbie-ai', admin=True)
instance = client.instance('visio-bt-staging')
connection = happybase.Connection(instance=instance)
connection.create_table('commons_TestBTModelsTable', {'family': None, 'counters': None})
table = connection.table('commons_TestBTModelsTable')
table.put('row-key1', {'family:surname': 'Trump'})
print("Getting row 'row-key1': {}".format(table.row(b'row-key1')))
table.counter_inc(b'row1', b'counters:qual1')
```
If I do `table.counter_inc(b'row1', 'counters:qual1')` is exactly the same.

When executed as script: 
```bash
root@2d21638ea17f:/app# python scripts/counters.py
Getting row 'row-key1': {b'family:surname': b'Trump'}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripts/counters.py", line 28, in <module>
    table.counter_inc(b'row1', b'counters:qual1')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/google/cloud/happybase/table.py", line 591, in counter_inc
    column_cells = modified_cells[column_family_id][column_qualifier]
KeyError: 'qual1'
```

Is it a bug or this snippet has a problem?

items.title: Performing a google.cloud.happybase Bigtable RowKeyRegexFilter Scan Not Working
items.body:
I'm trying to do row filtering by Key regex filter, everything is working like a charm (filter by prefix, filter by key start and stop range, by key, by keys) but I can't get it working passing in the `RowKeyRegexFilter` as filter, it just returns all the keys as an empty keys scan:

```python
# all the boilerplate to create a happybase connection skipped 
t = connection.table("sometable")
t.put(
    b'row1',
    {
       b"family1:col2": b".1",
       b"family2:col2": b".12",
    }
)
t.put(
    b'row2',
    {
       b"family1:col2": b".2",
       b"family2:col2": b".22",
    }
)
t.put(
    b'row3',
    {
       b"family1:col2": b".3",
       b"family2:col2": b".32",
    }
)
rows = t.scan(
    filter=RowKeyRegexFilter(b'.+3')
)
print(len([i for i in rows])
```

That gives always 3, no matter if you put `(nomatchforsure)+` as regex, I could not find any documentation with a working example, and the most amazing thing is that `google.cloud.happybase.table.Table.rows` performs a filter by row key always with `RowKeyRegexFilter`, but passing regex into `rows` method instead of real rows keys don't give regex filtering either, you can see it

here: [https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python-happybase/blob/master/src/google/cloud/happybase/table.py#L197][1]

and here: [https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python-happybase/blob/master/src/google/cloud/happybase/table.py#L971][2]

Any help on this would be very appreciated

[1]: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python-happybase/blob/4409d383f8207cf95726dbf9349acc16bfff44b9/src/google/cloud/happybase/table.py#L197
[2]: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python-happybase/blob/4409d383f8207cf95726dbf9349acc16bfff44b9/src/google/cloud/happybase/table.py#L971
